scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The records consist of organizational reports and correspondence, notices and flyers, publicity materials and background files on such topics as legislation, the merit system, payroll issues, school construction, job titles and whistle-blowers.
INVENTORY AVAILABLE IN REPOSITORY; CONTACT: tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu. NOTE: This collection is housed offsite and advance notice is required for use.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The Civil Service Merit Council was founded in 1971 by Alfred Engel (d. 2007), an engineer who had worked in many New York City agencies and was active as a chapter chairman in the Civil Service Technical Guild, Local 375 (AFSCME, DC 37), and attorney Julian Jackson. Engel became the councilâ€™s first president. The purpose of the Merit Council was to advocate for strict adherence to civil service examination results, and against patronage, favoritism, outsourcing and other abuses in civil service employment. It is a non-partisan coalition of individuals and organizations.
